message_1: Assuming that the universe of discourse D is the set of all real numbers, given the higher-order logical formula ∃F∀x(Fx ↔ x>3), what is the truth value of this formula?
message_2:
The higher-order logical formula ∃F∀x(Fx ↔ x>3) can be interpreted as follows: There exists a function F such that for all x in the set of real numbers, F(x) is true if and only if x > 3.

In this case, the truth value of the formula is true. This is because we can define a function F(x) that satisfies the given condition. For example, we can define F(x) as a function that returns true if x > 3 and false otherwise. Since such a function exists, the formula is true.
